sectionObjective: Talk about the risks and benefits of apps / Make an effective complaint about a product or service

sets.exerciseInstruction: Look at the highlighted sentences in the article. Underline the adjective clauses in each.
Work in pairs. Are the clauses you underlined in Exercise A essential or non-essential? How do you know?
Choose the sentences that match the rules.

sentences: In essential adjective clauses we can use that instead of who or which.
exerciseSentences.exerciseAnswers: In the past, we placed our trust in our neighbors – people in our local community that had developed a good reputation for the products and services they offered.
exerciseOptions: In the past, we placed our trust in our neighbors – people in our local community that had developed a good reputation for the products and services they offered.
Thanks to Uber, which lets people use an app to order a ride at a generally much lower rate than a normal taxi firm, we are all potential taxi drivers.

sentences: In essential adjective clauses we can omit the relative pronoun when it’s the object of the adjective clause.
exerciseSentences.exerciseAnswers: Recruiters now regularly check out people’s online profiles before interviewing or hiring them and the first thing they see are social media profiles.
exerciseOptions: Well, it’s not difficult to imagine a world where our every interaction affects a social credit score.
Recruiters now regularly check out people’s online profiles before interviewing or hiring them and the first thing they see are social media profiles.

sentences: In non-essential adjective clauses we use commas to separate the clause from the rest of the sentence
exerciseSentences.exerciseAnswers: Thanks to Uber, which lets people use an app to order a ride at a generally much lower rate than a normal taxi firm, we are all potential taxi drivers.
exerciseOptions: Thanks to Uber, which lets people use an app to order a ride at a generally much lower rate than a normal taxi firm, we are all potential taxi drivers.
Of course, we don’t all have the influence of famous celebrities, but companies now hire people whose job is to monitor mentions of their brands so they can provide instant customer support.

sentences: In both types of adjective clause we use where to talk about places d and whose to talk about possession e – neither of which can be omitted.
exerciseSentences.exerciseAnswers: Of course, we don’t all have the influence of famous celebrities, but companies now hire people whose job is to monitor mentions of their brands so they can provide instant customer support.
exerciseOptions: Of course, we don’t all have the influence of famous celebrities, but companies now hire people whose job is to monitor mentions of their brands so they can provide instant customer support.
In the past, we placed our trust in our neighbors – people in our local community that had developed a good reputation for the products and services they offered.

sentences: In both types of adjective clause we use prepositions at the beginning of a clause in formal English and at the end in informal English.
exerciseSentences.exerciseAnswers: Who are the people in your life that you place your trust in?
exerciseOptions: In the past, we placed our trust in our neighbors – people in our local community that had developed a good reputation for the products and services they offered.
Who are the people in your life that you place your trust in?

sets.exerciseInstruction: Go to the Grammar Hub on page 138.
Work in pairs. Try to improve the following review using adjective clauses like the one in the example.
Choose the correct options to complete the sentences.

sentences: Last summer, I visited my cousin, ____ lives in a nice apartment in New York.
There’s the new store ____ I was telling you about.
The recruiter ____ helped is my cousin, Léo.
The woman ____ house we stayed in had listed it on Airbnb.
It’s usually late at night where / when I feel hungriest.
